transcript.title: Interview with David Koch and Natalie Barr, Sunrise, Seven Network
transcript.subjects: Malaysia Airlines aircraft, Racial Discrimination Act, a new honour for pre-eminent Australians.
transcript.content:
DAVID KOCH:

Good morning to you, Prime Minister.

PRIME MINISTER:

Good morning Kochie.

DAVID KOCH:

Any new information on the investigation this morning?

PRIME MINISTER:

We will have later today, we think, some Chinese naval vessels joining HMAS Success in the search area. There is another Australian Naval vessel that will be joining operations in the next few days. Black box recovery equipment is coming to Australia, so weâre doing everything we humanly can.

Yesterday I spoke to Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia and assured him that Australia stood ready to offer every possible assistance.

DAVID KOCH:

NATALIE BARR:

Ok look, just such a big job ahead.

Yesterday we tried to get rid of the mining tax â the Labor Party voted to keep it, so weâre stuck with that for the time being.

But this is a Government which can do several things at once and yes, yesterday we released an exposure draft of legislation which keeps the red light on racism, but which removed the amber light on free speech which had existed since the Bolt case a couple of years ago where, as you know, Andrew Bolt was successfully prosecuted on the basis on an article that heâd written.

NATALIE BARR:

But youâve got, you know, obviously the Brandis comments about you know, everyone has a right to be a bigot created huge storm this week and youâve got people like Senator Nova Perris saying those comments are a green light to racism and other sorts of hate speech. PRIME MINISTER:

Now, the laws that we are proposing do actually make racial vilification an offence; in fact in many respects theyâre stronger than the laws that they will replace. But what we are going to do is ensure that youâve got strong safeguards against racial vilification but strong protections of the right of free speech.

DAVID KOCH:

Ok. You shocked everyone yesterday by bringing back knighthoods and do you call them damehoods, or Dames? Anyhow, why do we need another level of honour here in Australia?

PRIME MINISTER:

This is going to be a very rare honour; only four a year at a maximum. The first new Dame will be Dame Quentin Bryce, the outgoing Governor-General. The first new Knight will be General Peter Cosgrove, the incoming Governor-General. This is an honour that will be reserved for a very small number of Australians who have served our country in an extraordinary and pre-eminent way.

Look, I think it is fitting â itâs fitting â that people who have given service of the quality and length and strength of Dame Quentin Bryce should be appropriately honoured.

DAVID KOCH:

PRIME MINISTER:

Look, heâs a terrific cricketer but I donât think weâre going to see Sir Shane any time soon.

DAVID KOCH:

Oh thatâs a slap down from the Prime Minister!

Prime Minister, thank you for that and also congratulations as well â 20 years today that you entered Parliament. Thatâs an enormous amount of community service, so well done.

PRIME MINISTER:

Well Kochie, thank you.

Look, itâs been an honour to serve. Every day is a privilege and I look forward to quite a few more years.

DAVID KOCH:

Ok. Good on you, thank you for joining us.

NATALIE BARR:
